SEA-3, LLC WHOLESALE PROPANE (LPG) IMPORT AND DISTRIBUTION TERMINAL

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary.  The entire summary was updated as Sea-3 Inc. was purchased in November 2017 and had a name change to Sea-3 LLC (Sea-3).   This resubmittal is to ensure compliance with EPA's 40-CFR 68 Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements.



1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Constructed in 1974-75, the Sea-3, LLC Newington Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Terminal provides a vital energy service to homeowners, commercial businesses, and industry.  The facility has an excellent safety record, and its employees and management are key players in achieving that exemplary safety record.



Sea-3 is committed to safe and reliable operations for the protection of its employees, the community, and the environment.  Sea-3 is proud of its 43 year operating record, during which there has never been an incident that resulted in any off-site impacts to neighboring industries, residents, the environment or the community at large.  This record has been achieved through consistent attention and total dedication by management and staff to safe operating practices and preventive maintenance.  Sea-3 has consistently made new investments in the latest technology in operating and maintaining the facility.  These practices form the backbone of Sea-3's dedication to keeping the facility, community and environment safe.



Sea-3 has extensive environmental, health and safety policies and procedures as required by the EPA, OSHA and US-Coast Guard as well and internal Sea-3 corporate policy.  These P&Ps cover the safe procedures for operation and are reviewed annually and kept current:  PSM and RMP Accident Prevention Program policies include but are not limited to:

2. DESCRIPTION OF THE SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The Sea-3 Terminal in Newingt

on, NH imports and stores fully refrigerated liquid propane also called LPG at -45 degrees Fahrenheit (?F).  The terminal processes this product by heating it to +40 ?F and loading it onto transport trucks for shipment out.  Ethyl mercaptan, an odorizing agent, is added to all the LPG being distributed from the terminal.  Both propane and ethyl mercaptan are regulated flammable RMP and PSM substances held above their threshold quantity.  The terminal is absent any RMP or PSM listed toxic chemicals at or above threshold quantities.





3. RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



The terminal was designed and built in accordance with provisions of the following three recognized standards for LPG facilities:



*NFPA 58, Standard for the Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases, (National Fire Protection Association).



*API 2510, Design and Construction of Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Installations, (American Petroleum Institute).



*API 620, Design and Construction of Large, Welded, Low-Pressure Storage Tanks, (American Petroleum Institute).



Operating areas of the plant are monitored by combustible vapor detectors that quickly detect any leaks.  Ultraviolet flame detectors monitor the plant to detect fires.  The plant is attended by at least two operators at all times.  They log field operating data at two-hour intervals and monitor plant equipment using the following monitoring and control systems:



*The main control panel located in the central control room displays pressures, temperatures, valve positions, and flow rates and provides for remote operation and manual or automatic shutdown of valves and equipment.



*The emergency control panel also located in the central control room displays readings of combustible vapor detectors and fire detectors.  It provides fire department notification and manual and automatic activation of water deluge and emergency shutdown systems.



*A closed circuit television (CCTV) system, with displays located in the central

control room, is used for surveillance and security of all portions of the terminal as well as the key operating areas.



Written policies and procedures and accident release prevention policies (some listed in section 1).  Besides these there are safe operation P&Ps contained in the following Sea-3 manuals:



*"Sea-3 Standard Operating Procedures Manual," covering normal startup, operation, and shutdown of plant systems and equipment.



*"Sea-3 Safety Standards and Procedures Manual," covering safe handling of the product and other materials used in the plant.  It covers safe work practices and permitting requirements for such activities as hot work, electrical work, lockout/tagout, confined space and vessel entry, excavation, and other hazardous activities.  Plant security and visitor policies are also included.



*"Sea-3 US Coast Guard Operating and Emergency Procedures Manual," covering operation of the marine transfer portion of the terminal as required by 33 CFR 127. 



*"Sea-3 Contingency Plan" covering responses by facility employees, the Newington Fire and Police Departments, and the US Coast Guard.  Its purpose is to minimize the effects of an incident at the terminal and to provide protection for persons and property in the area.  It includes plans for sounding an alarm, initial response, determination of need for additional assistance, flammable vapor control, firefighting, first aid, evacuation of personnel and nearby residents, mutual aid support and propane industry group response.



*"Sea-3 Mooring Policy and Procedure Manual" covering the safe mooring of LPG carriers at the berth during cargo transfers. 



*"Sea-3 Facility Security Plan" covering security as required by the US Department of Homeland Security, as well as PSM and RMP regulations.



*"Sea-3 Process Safety Management Manual," covering the elements of Process Safety Management, including employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating proced

ures, training, contractor evaluation and training, truck driver (non-employee) evaluation and training, pre-startup safety reviews, equipment mechanical integrity, safe work permit system, management of change, incident investigation, and emergency preparedness.  The complete list is included in Section 1 Accident Release Prevention Program.





4. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



In the five-year reporting period, there have been no propane or ethyl mercaptan releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.





5. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Emergency planning and preparedness are covered in the "Sea-3 Contingency Plan," which details responses by facility employees, the Newington Fire and Police Departments, and the US Coast Guard.  These agencies were involved in the development of the plan which is available to all cognizant officials in the pamphlet "Sea-3 Emergency Procedures."  The sections involving facility employees were developed by Sea-3 management in conjunction with the operating staff and outside consultants.  All new employees are given initial training in health safety and emergency and operation procedures.  Employees receive refresher training on an ongoing basis.  This training is documented in accordance with the training records requirements of OSHA's Process Safety Management program and EPA's Risk Management Program.  Sea-3 staff receive Fire School Classroom and live Training .



In addition to the Sea-3 Emergency Procedures noted above, emergency response is also covered in the "Sea-3 US Coast Guard Operating and Emergency Procedures Manual."  The US Coast Guard also maintains its own written operating and emergency plan, "Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Contingency Plan," issued by the USCG Marine Safety Office in Portland, Maine.





6. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The facility has bee

n in operation since 1975.  Safety reviews as well as compliance audits; Process Hazards Analysis, etc., have been undertaken periodically since that time.  Many recommendations arising from these reviews have been implemented through equipment additions and or changes as well as procedural changes.



The most recent review was a process hazard analysis (PHA) completed on April 27, 2017.  All issues identified during that review were addressed and resolved by the end of that year.  



Based on the new ownership of Sea-3, all environmental health and safety programs are being reviewed to ensure they meet OSHA, EPA, USCG and our parent company Blackline Partners, LLC's safety standards.  There are future plans to upgrade the railcar receiving and increase propane storage capabilities.
